<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-2010_Winter_Olympics skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">2010 Winter Olympics</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="dablink">"2010 Olympics" redirects here. For the Youth Olympics, see <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Summer Youth Olympics (page does not exist)">2010 Summer Youth Olympics</a>.</div>
<div class="dablink">"Vancouver 2010" redirects here. For the video game, see <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vancouver_2010_(video_game)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vancouver 2010 (video game) (page does not exist)">Vancouver 2010 (video game)</a>.&#32;&#32;For the Winter Games for athletes with a physical disability, see <a href="/wiki/2010_Winter_Paralympics" title="2010 Winter Paralympics">2010 Winter Paralympics</a>.</div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_mdy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use mdy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use mdy dates</a>
</p><p>{{#invoke:Infobox|infobox}}
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Template:2010 Winter Olympics</a>
</p><p>The <b>2010 Winter Olympics</b>, officially known as the <b>XXI Olympic Winter Games</b> or the 21st <a href="/wiki/Winter_Olympics" title="Winter Olympics" class="mw-redirect">Winter Olympics</a>, were a major international <a href="/wiki/Multi-sport_event" title="Multi-sport event">multi-sport event</a> held from February 12 to February 28, 2010, in <a href="/wiki/Vancouver" title="Vancouver">Vancouver</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Columbia" title="British Columbia">British Columbia</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Canada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Canada (page does not exist)">Canada</a>, with some events held in the suburbs of <a href="/wiki/Richmond,_British_Columbia" title="Richmond, British Columbia">Richmond</a>, <a href="/wiki/West_Vancouver" title="West Vancouver">West Vancouver</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_Endowment_Lands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University Endowment Lands (page does not exist)">University Endowment Lands</a>, and in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Resort_town&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Resort town (page does not exist)">resort town</a> of <a href="/wiki/Whistler,_British_Columbia" title="Whistler, British Columbia">Whistler</a>.  Approximately 2,600 athletes from 82 nations participated in 86 events in fifteen disciplines. Both the Olympic and <a href="/wiki/2010_Winter_Paralympics" title="2010 Winter Paralympics">Paralympic Games</a> were being organized by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vancouver_Organizing_Committee_for_the_2010_Olympic_and_Paralympic_Winter_Games&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vancouver Organizing Committee for the 2010 Olympic and Paralympic Winter Games (page does not exist)">Vancouver Organizing Committee</a> (VANOC), headed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Furlong_(CEO)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Furlong (CEO) (page does not exist)">John Furlong</a>. The 2010 Winter Olympics were the third <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympics</a> hosted by Canada and the first by the province of British Columbia.  Previously, Canada hosted the <a href="/wiki/1976_Summer_Olympics" title="1976 Summer Olympics">1976 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Montreal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Montreal (page does not exist)">Montreal</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Quebec&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Quebec (page does not exist)">Quebec</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/1988_Winter_Olympics" title="1988 Winter Olympics">1988 Winter Olympics</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Calgary&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Calgary (page does not exist)">Calgary</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alberta" title="Alberta">Alberta</a>. The 2010 Winter Olympics had three mascots.
</p><p>Following Olympic tradition, then-Vancouver mayor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sam_Sullivan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sam Sullivan (page does not exist)">Sam Sullivan</a> received the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_symbols" title="Olympic symbols">Olympic flag</a> during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2006_Winter_Olympics_closing_ceremony&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2006 Winter Olympics closing ceremony (page does not exist)">closing ceremony of the 2006 Winter Olympics</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Turin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Turin (page does not exist)">Turin</a>, Italy. The flag was raised on February 28, 2006, in a special ceremony and was on display at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vancouver_City_Hall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vancouver City Hall (page does not exist)">Vancouver City Hall</a> until the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Winter_Olympics_opening_ceremony&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Winter Olympics opening ceremony (page does not exist)">Olympic opening ceremony</a>. The event was officially opened by <a href="/wiki/Governor_General_of_Canada" title="Governor General of Canada">Governor General</a> <a href="/wiki/Micha%C3%ABlle_Jean" title="Michaëlle Jean">Michaëlle Jean</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-govgen_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-govgen-1">[1]</a></sup> who was accompanied by Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Harper" title="Stephen Harper">Stephen Harper</a> and International Olympic Committee president <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Rogge" title="Jacques Rogge">Jacques Rogge</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>For the first time, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Canada_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Canada at the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Canada</a> won gold in an <a href="/wiki/Olympic_sports" title="Olympic sports">"official" sport</a> at an Olympic Games hosted at home, having failed to do so at both the <a href="/wiki/1976_Summer_Olympics" title="1976 Summer Olympics">1976 Summer Olympics</a> in Montreal and the <a href="/wiki/1988_Winter_Olympics" title="1988 Winter Olympics">1988 Winter Olympics</a> in Calgary (although Canada won a gold medal in the "demonstration-sport" of curling in Calgary). Canada clinched their first gold medal on the second day of the competition and first topped the gold medal tally on the second to last day of competition and went on to became the first host nation since <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway_at_the_1952_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Norway at the 1952 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Norway in 1952</a> to lead the gold medal count.<sup id="cite_ref-clinch_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-clinch-3">[3]</a></sup> With 14, Canada broke the record for the most gold medals won at a single Winter Olympics, which was 13, set by the former <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soviet_Union_at_the_1976_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soviet Union at the 1976 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Soviet Union in 1976</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norway_at_the_2002_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Norway at the 2002 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Norway in 2002</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-RecordGolds_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RecordGolds-4">[4]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States at the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">United States won the most medals</a> in total, their second time doing so at the Winter Olympics, and broke the record for the most medals won at a single Winter Olympics with 37, a record held up to then by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Germany_at_the_2002_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Germany at the 2002 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Germany in 2002</a> with 36 medals.<sup id="cite_ref-clinch_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-clinch-3">[3]</a></sup> Athletes from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovakia_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Slovakia at the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Slovakia</a><sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Belarus_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Belarus at the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Belarus</a><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> won the first Winter Olympic gold medals for their nations.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Bid_and_preparations">Bid and preparations</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin-right:1.5em; margin:10px">

<tr>
<th colspan="6"> 2010 Winter Olympics bidding results<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</th></tr>
<tr style="background:#ccc;">
<td> <b>City</b>
</td>
<td> <b>Nation</b>
</td>
<td> <b>Round 1</b>
</td>
<td> <b>Round 2</b>
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#efefef;">
<td> <a href="/wiki/Vancouver" title="Vancouver">Vancouver</a></td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Canada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Canada (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Canada</a>
</td>
<td align="center">40</td>
<td align="center"><b>56</b>
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#efefef;">
<td> <a href="/wiki/Pyeongchang" title="Pyeongchang" class="mw-redirect">Pyeongchang</a></td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_South_Korea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data South Korea (page does not exist)">Template:Country data South Korea</a>
</td>
<td align="center"><b>51</b></td>
<td align="center">53
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#efefef;">
<td> <a href="/wiki/Salzburg" title="Salzburg">Salzburg</a></td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Austria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Austria (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Austria</a>
</td>
<td align="center">16</td>
<td align="center">—
</td></tr></table>
<p>The Canadian Olympic Association chose Vancouver as the Canadian candidate city over Calgary, which sought to re-host the Games and <a href="/wiki/Quebec_City" title="Quebec City">Quebec City</a>, which had lost the 2002 Olympic bid in 1995. On the first round of voting on November 21, 1998, Vancouver-Whistler had 26 votes, Quebec City had 25 and Calgary had 21. On December 3, 1998, the second and final round of voting occurred between the two leading contenders, which saw Vancouver win with 40 votes compared to Quebec City's 32 votes.
</p><p>After the <a href="/wiki/2002_Winter_Olympic_bid_scandal" title="2002 Winter Olympic bid scandal">bribery scandal</a> over the candidacy of the <a href="/wiki/Salt_Lake_City" title="Salt Lake City">Salt Lake City</a> bid for the <a href="/wiki/2002_Winter_Olympics" title="2002 Winter Olympics">2002 Winter Olympics</a> (which resulted in Quebec City asking for compensation (C$8 million) for its unsuccessful bid),<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> many of the rules of the bidding process were changed in 1999. The <a href="/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee" title="International Olympic Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> (IOC) created the Evaluation Commission, which was appointed on October 24, 2002. Prior to the bidding for the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a>, host cities would often fly members of the IOC to their city where they toured the city and were provided with gifts. The lack of oversight and transparency often led to allegations of money for votes. Afterward, changes brought forth by the IOC bidding rules were tightened, and more focused on technical aspects of candidate cities. The team analyzed the candidate city features and provided its input back to the IOC.
</p><p>Vancouver won the bid to host the Olympics by a vote of the International Olympic Committee on July 2, 2003, at the 115th IOC Session held in <a href="/wiki/Prague" title="Prague">Prague</a>, Czech Republic. The result was announced by IOC President <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Rogge" title="Jacques Rogge">Jacques Rogge</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> Vancouver faced two other finalists shortlisted that same February: <a href="/wiki/Pyeongchang_County" title="Pyeongchang County">Pyeongchang</a>, South Korea, and <a href="/wiki/Salzburg" title="Salzburg">Salzburg</a>, Austria. Pyeongchang had the most votes of the three cities in the first round of voting, in which Salzburg was eliminated. In the run-off, all but two of the members who had voted for Salzburg voted for Vancouver. It was the closest vote by the IOC since Sydney, Australia beat Beijing for the 2000 Summer Olympics by two votes. Vancouver's victory came almost two years after Toronto's <a href="/wiki/Bids_for_the_2008_Summer_Olympics" title="Bids for the 2008 Summer Olympics">2008 Summer Olympic bid</a> was defeated by Beijing in a landslide vote.
</p><p>The Vancouver Olympic Committee (VANOC) spent C$16.6 million on upgrading facilities at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cypress_Mountain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cypress Mountain (page does not exist)">Cypress Mountain</a>, which hosted the freestyle (aerials, moguls, ski cross) and snowboarding events. With the opening in February 2009 of the C$40&#160;million <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vancouver_Olympic/Paralympic_Centre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vancouver Olympic/Paralympic Centre (page does not exist)">Vancouver Olympic/Paralympic Centre</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hillcrest_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hillcrest Park (page does not exist)">Hillcrest Park</a>, which hosted curling, every sports venue for the 2010 Games was completed on time and at least one year prior to the Games.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Financials">Financials</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Operations">Operations</span></h3>
<p>In 2004, the operational cost of the 2010 Winter Olympics was estimated to be Canadian $1.354&#160;billion (about <a href="/w/index.php?title=%C2%A3&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="£ (page does not exist)">£</a>828,499,787, <a href="/wiki/%E2%82%AC" title="€" class="mw-redirect">€</a>975,033,598 or <a href="/wiki/US$" title="US$" class="mw-redirect">US$</a>1,314,307,896). As of mid-2009 it was projected to be C$1.76&#160;billion,<sup id="cite_ref-huffingtonpost1_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-huffingtonpost1-12">[12]</a></sup> mostly raised from non-government sources,<sup id="cite_ref-huffingtonpost1_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-huffingtonpost1-12">[12]</a></sup> primarily through sponsorships and the auction of national broadcasting rights. C$580&#160;million was the taxpayer-supported budget to construct or renovate venues throughout Vancouver and Whistler. A final audit conducted by <a href="/wiki/PricewaterhouseCoopers" title="PricewaterhouseCoopers">PricewaterhouseCoopers</a> released in December 2010 revealed total operation cost to have been $1.84 billion and came in on budget resulting in neither surplus nor deficit. Construction of venues also came on budget with a total cost of $603 million.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>PricewaterhouseCoopers' study estimated a total contribution to the BC economy of $2.5 billion of Gross Domestic Product, and as well created 45,000 jobs and contributed an additional $463 million to the tourism industry while venue construction by VANOC and 3rd parties added $1.22 billion to the economy.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Security_costs">Security costs</span></h3>
<p>C$200&#160;million was expected to be spent for security, which was organized through a special body, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Integrated_Security_Unit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Integrated Security Unit (page does not exist)">Integrated Security Unit</a>, of which the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Canadian_Mounted_Police" title="Royal Canadian Mounted Police">Royal Canadian Mounted Police</a> (RCMP) was the lead agency; other government agencies such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vancouver_Police_Department&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vancouver Police Department (page does not exist)">Vancouver Police Department</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canada_Border_Services_Agency" title="Canada Border Services Agency">Canada Border Services Agency</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Forces" title="Canadian Forces">Canadian Forces</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Law_enforcement_in_Canada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Law enforcement in Canada (page does not exist)">police agencies across Canada</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Security_Intelligence_Service" title="Canadian Security Intelligence Service">Canadian Security Intelligence Service</a> (CSIS) also played a role. That number was later revealed to be in the region of C$1&#160;billion, an amount in excess of five times what was originally estimated.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Venues">Venues</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Richmond_Olympic_Oval_front_view.jpg" title="File:Richmond Olympic Oval front view.jpg">File:Richmond Olympic Oval front view.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Richmond_Olympic_Oval&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Richmond Olympic Oval (page does not exist)">Richmond Olympic Oval</a>: speed skating long track venue</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Some venues, including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Richmond_Olympic_Oval&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Richmond Olympic Oval (page does not exist)">Richmond Olympic Oval</a>, were at sea level, a rarity for the Winter Games.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> The 2010 Games were also the first—Winter or Summer—to have had an Opening Ceremony held indoors.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> Vancouver was the most populous city ever to hold the Winter Games.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> In February, the month when the Games were held, Vancouver has an average temperature of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> The average temperature as measured at <a href="/wiki/Vancouver_International_Airport" title="Vancouver International Airport">Vancouver International Airport</a> was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> for the month of February 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p><p>The opening and closing ceremonies were held at <a href="/w/index.php?title=BC_Place_Stadium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BC Place Stadium (page does not exist)">BC Place Stadium</a>, which received over C$150&#160;million in major renovations. Competition venues in Greater Vancouver included the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Coliseum" title="Pacific Coliseum">Pacific Coliseum</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vancouver_Olympic/Paralympic_Centre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vancouver Olympic/Paralympic Centre (page does not exist)">Vancouver Olympic/Paralympic Centre</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=UBC_Winter_Sports_Centre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UBC Winter Sports Centre (page does not exist)">UBC Winter Sports Centre</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Richmond_Olympic_Oval&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Richmond Olympic Oval (page does not exist)">Richmond Olympic Oval</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cypress_Mountain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cypress Mountain (page does not exist)">Cypress Mountain</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=GM_Place&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="GM Place (page does not exist)">GM Place</a> (now known as <a href="/wiki/Rogers_Arena" title="Rogers Arena">Rogers Arena</a>), home of the NHL's <a href="/wiki/Vancouver_Canucks" title="Vancouver Canucks">Vancouver Canucks</a>, played host to <a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey" title="Ice hockey">ice hockey</a> events, but because corporate sponsorship is not allowed for an Olympic venue, it was renamed Canada Hockey Place for the duration of the Games.<sup id="cite_ref-chp_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chp-20">[20]</a></sup> Renovations included the removal of advertising from the ice surface and conversion of some seating to accommodate the media.<sup id="cite_ref-chp_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chp-20">[20]</a></sup> The 2010 Winter Olympics marked the first time an Olympic hockey game was played on a rink sized according to NHL rules instead of <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_Ice_Hockey_Federation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International Ice Hockey Federation (page does not exist)">international</a> specifications. Competition venues in Whistler included Whistler Creekside at the <a href="/wiki/Whistler_Blackcomb" title="Whistler Blackcomb">Whistler Blackcomb</a> ski resort, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Whistler_Olympic_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Whistler Olympic Park (page does not exist)">Whistler Olympic Park</a>, the Whistler Celebration Plaza and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Whistler_Sliding_Centre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Whistler Sliding Centre (page does not exist)">Whistler Sliding Centre</a>.
</p><p>The 2010 Winter Games marked the first time that the energy consumption of the Olympic venues was tracked in real time and made available to the public. Energy data was collected from the metering and building automation systems of nine of the Olympic venues and was displayed online through the Venue Energy Tracker project.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Marketing">Marketing</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vrh_Vislera_-_Simbol_Olimpijade_2010.JPG" title="File:Vrh Vislera - Simbol Olimpijade 2010.JPG">File:Vrh Vislera - Simbol Olimpijade 2010.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A statue of Ilanaaq, located on Whistler Mountain.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Leo_Obstbaum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leo Obstbaum (page does not exist)">Leo Obstbaum</a> (1969–2009), the late director of design for the 2010 Winter Olympics, oversaw and designed many of the main symbols of the Games, including the mascots, medals and the design of the Olympic torches.<sup id="cite_ref-ctv_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ctv-22">[22]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 2010 Winter Olympics logo was unveiled on April 23, 2005, and is named Ilanaaq the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Inunnguaq&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Inunnguaq (page does not exist)">Inunnguaq</a>. Ilanaaq is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Inuktitut_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Inuktitut language (page does not exist)">Inuktitut</a> word for <i>friend</i>. The logo was based on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Inukshuk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Inukshuk (page does not exist)">Inukshuk</a> (stone landmark or cairn) built for the Northwest Territories Pavilion at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Expo_86&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Expo 86 (page does not exist)">Expo 86</a> and donated to the City of Vancouver after the event. It is now used as a landmark on <a href="/w/index.php?title=English_Bay_Beach&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="English Bay Beach (page does not exist)">English Bay Beach</a>.
</p><p>The mascots for the 2010 Winter Olympic and Paralympic Games were designed by Vicki Wong and Michael C. Murphy of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Meomi_Design&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Meomi Design (page does not exist)">Meomi Design</a> and introduced on November 27, 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> Inspired by traditional <a href="/wiki/First_Nations" title="First Nations">First Nations</a> creatures, the mascots include:
</p>
<ul>
<li> <i>Miga</i> — A mythical sea bear, part <a href="/w/index.php?title=Orca&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Orca (page does not exist)">orca</a> and part <a href="/wiki/Kermode_bear" title="Kermode bear">Kermode bear</a>.
</li>
<li> <i>Quatchi</i> — A <a href="/wiki/Bigfoot" title="Bigfoot">sasquatch</a>, who wears winter boots and blue earmuffs.
</li>
<li> <i>Sumi</i> — An animal guardian spirit who wears the hat of an orca whale, flies with the wings of the mighty <a href="/wiki/Thunderbird_(mythology)" title="Thunderbird (mythology)">Thunderbird</a> and runs on the strong furry legs of a <a href="/wiki/American_black_bear" title="American black bear">black bear</a>.
</li>
<li> <i>Mukmuk</i> — A <a href="/wiki/Vancouver_Island_marmot" title="Vancouver Island marmot">Vancouver Island marmot</a>.<sup class="reference" id="ref_note01"><a href="#endnote_note01">[A]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Canadian_Mint" title="Royal Canadian Mint">Royal Canadian Mint</a> produced a series of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Canadian_Mint_Olympic_coins&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Canadian Mint Olympic coins (page does not exist)">commemorative coins</a> celebrating the 2010 Games,<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> and in partnership with <a href="/wiki/CTV_Television_Network" title="CTV Television Network">CTV</a> allowed users to vote on the <i>Top 10 Canadian Olympic Winter Moments</i>; where designs honouring the top three were added to the series of coins.<sup id="cite_ref-np-moment_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-np-moment-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p><p>Canada Post released many stamps to commemorate the Vancouver Games including, one for each of the mascots and one to celebrate the first Gold won in Canada. Many countries' postal services have also released stamps, such as the US,<sup id="cite_ref-USPS-Vancouver_2010_Olympic_Winter_Games_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USPS-Vancouver_2010_Olympic_Winter_Games-26">[26]</a></sup> Germany,<sup id="cite_ref-Weltweite_Sportereignisse_-_Olympische_Winterspiele_2010_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Weltweite_Sportereignisse_-_Olympische_Winterspiele_2010-27">[27]</a></sup> Australia (who present medallist with a copy of the stamps depicting their image),<sup id="cite_ref-Australia_Post-2010_Olympic_Winter_Gold_Medallist_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Australia_Post-2010_Olympic_Winter_Gold_Medallist-28">[28]</a></sup> Austria,<sup id="cite_ref-Karl_Benjamin_-_Viererblock_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Karl_Benjamin_-_Viererblock-29">[29]</a></sup> Belarus,<sup id="cite_ref-XXI_Olympic_Winter_Games_in_Vancouver_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-XXI_Olympic_Winter_Games_in_Vancouver-30">[30]</a></sup> Croatia,<sup id="cite_ref-Commemorative_postage_stamps_HP_Mostar_-_XXI._Zimske_olimpijske_igre_Vancouver_2010._Winter_Olympics_Vancouver_2010_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Commemorative_postage_stamps_HP_Mostar_-_XXI._Zimske_olimpijske_igre_Vancouver_2010._Winter_Olympics_Vancouver_2010-31">[31]</a></sup> Czech Republic,<sup id="cite_ref-XXI._zimn.C3.AD_olympijsk.C3.A9_hry_Vancouver_2010_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-XXI._zimn.C3.AD_olympijsk.C3.A9_hry_Vancouver_2010-32">[32]</a></sup> Estonia,<sup id="cite_ref-XXI_taliol.C3.BCmpiam.C3.A4ngud_Vancouveris_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-XXI_taliol.C3.BCmpiam.C3.A4ngud_Vancouveris-33">[33]</a></sup> France,<sup id="cite_ref-La_Poste-Diptyque_J.O._d.27Hiver_de_Vancouver_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-La_Poste-Diptyque_J.O._d.27Hiver_de_Vancouver-34">[34]</a></sup> Italy,<sup id="cite_ref-Winter_Olympic_Games_.E2.80.9CVancouver_2010.E2.80.9D_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Winter_Olympic_Games_.E2.80.9CVancouver_2010.E2.80.9D-35">[35]</a></sup> Liechtenstein,<sup id="cite_ref-Olympische_Winterspiele_Vancouver_2010_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Olympische_Winterspiele_Vancouver_2010-36">[36]</a></sup> Lithuania,<sup id="cite_ref-XXI_Olympic_Winter_Games_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-XXI_Olympic_Winter_Games-37">[37]</a></sup> Poland,<sup id="cite_ref-VANCOUVER_2010_OLYMPIC_WINTER_GAMES_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VANCOUVER_2010_OLYMPIC_WINTER_GAMES-38">[38]</a></sup> Switzerland,<sup id="cite_ref-Einzelmarke_gestempelt_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Einzelmarke_gestempelt-39">[39]</a></sup> Turkey<sup id="cite_ref-XXI.KI.C5.9E_OL.C4.B0MP.C4.B0YATLARI_XXI._OLYMPIC_WINTER_GAMES_XXI.WINTEROLYMPIADE_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-XXI.KI.C5.9E_OL.C4.B0MP.C4.B0YATLARI_XXI._OLYMPIC_WINTER_GAMES_XXI.WINTEROLYMPIADE-40">[40]</a></sup> and Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-XXI_Winter_Olympic_Games._Vancouver-2010_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-XXI_Winter_Olympic_Games._Vancouver-2010-41">[41]</a></sup>
</p><p>Two official video games have been released to commemorate the Games: <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_and_Sonic_at_the_Olympic_Winter_Games&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mario and Sonic at the Olympic Winter Games (page does not exist)">Mario and Sonic at the Olympic Winter Games</a></i> was released for <a href="/wiki/Wii" title="Wii">Wii</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nintendo_DS" title="Nintendo DS">Nintendo DS</a> in October 2009, while <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vancouver_2010_(video_game)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vancouver 2010 (video game) (page does not exist)">Vancouver 2010</a></i> was released in January 2010 for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Xbox_360&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Xbox 360 (page does not exist)">Xbox 360</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Games_for_Windows&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Games for Windows (page does not exist)">Windows</a> and <a href="/wiki/PlayStation_3" title="PlayStation 3">PlayStation 3</a>. The official theme songs for the 2010 Winter Games used by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Canada%27s_Olympic_Broadcast_Media_Consortium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Canada's Olympic Broadcast Media Consortium (page does not exist)">Canada's Olympic Broadcast Media Consortium</a> (commonly known as CTV Olympics) were "<a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Believe_(Nikki_Yanofsky_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Believe (Nikki Yanofsky song) (page does not exist)">I Believe</a>" performed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nikki_Yanofsky&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nikki Yanofsky (page does not exist)">Nikki Yanofsky</a> and "J'imagine" performed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Annie_Villeneuve&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Annie Villeneuve (page does not exist)">Annie Villeneuve</a>.
</p><p>Three albums, <i>Canada's Hockey Anthems: Sounds of the Vancouver 2010 Winter Olympic Games</i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Winter_Olympics_opening_ceremony&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Winter Olympics opening ceremony (page does not exist)">Sounds of Vancouver 2010: Opening Ceremony Commemorative Album</a></i>, and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Winter_Olympics_closing_ceremony&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Winter Olympics closing ceremony (page does not exist)">Sounds of Vancouver 2010: Closing Ceremony Commemorative Album</a></i>, composed, arranged and produced by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dave_Pierce&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dave Pierce (page does not exist)">Dave Pierce</a>, were released to accompany the Games.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> Pierce's Music Direction for the Opening and Closing Ceremonies led him to win the Primetime <a href="/wiki/Emmy_Award" title="Emmy Award">Emmy Award</a> for "Outstanding Music Direction" in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Media_coverage">Media coverage</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The Olympic Games in Vancouver were broadcast worldwide by a number of television broadcasters. As rights for the 2010 Games have been packaged with those for the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a>, broadcasters were largely identical for both events.
</p><p>The host broadcaster was Olympic Broadcasting Services Vancouver, a subsidiary of the IOC's new in-house broadcasting unit <a href="/w/index.php?title=Olympic_Broadcasting_Services&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Olympic Broadcasting Services (page does not exist)">Olympic Broadcasting Services</a> (OBS). The 2010 Olympics marked the first Games where the host broadcasting facilities were provided solely by OBS.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> The executive director of Olympic Broadcasting Services Vancouver was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nancy_Lee_(producer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nancy Lee (producer) (page does not exist)">Nancy Lee</a>, a former producer and executive for <a href="/w/index.php?title=CBC_Sports&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="CBC Sports (page does not exist)">CBC Sports</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-lee_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lee-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Canada, the Games were the first Olympic Games broadcast by a new Olympic Broadcast Media Consortium led by <a href="/w/index.php?title=CTVglobemedia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="CTVglobemedia (page does not exist)">CTVglobemedia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rogers_Media" title="Rogers Media">Rogers Media</a>, displacing previous broadcaster <a href="/w/index.php?title=CBC_Sports&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="CBC Sports (page does not exist)">CBC Sports</a>. Main English-language coverage was shown on the <a href="/wiki/CTV_Television_Network" title="CTV Television Network">CTV Television Network</a>, while supplementary programming was mainly shown on <a href="/wiki/The_Sports_Network" title="The Sports Network">TSN</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rogers_Sportsnet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rogers Sportsnet (page does not exist)">Rogers Sportsnet</a>. Main French-language coverage was shown on <a href="/wiki/V_(TV_network)" title="V (TV network)">V</a> and <a href="/wiki/R%C3%A9seau_des_sports" title="Réseau des sports">RDS</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the United States, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Associated_Press&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Associated Press (page does not exist)">Associated Press</a> (AP) announced that it would send 120 reporters, photographers, editors and videographers to cover the Games on behalf of the country's <a href="/wiki/News_media" title="News media">news media</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-eandp10_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eandp10-47">[47]</a></sup>  The cost of their Olympics coverage prompted AP to make a "real departure for the <a href="/wiki/Wire_service" title="Wire service" class="mw-redirect">wire service</a>'s online coverage". Rather than simply providing content, it partnered with more than 900 newspapers and broadcasters who split the ad revenue generated from an AP-produced multi-media package of video, photos, statistics, stories and a daily Webcast.<sup id="cite_ref-eandp10_47-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eandp10-47">[47]</a></sup>  AP's coverage included a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsite&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsite (page does not exist)">microsite</a> with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Web_widget&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Web widget (page does not exist)">web widgets</a> facilitating integration with <a href="/wiki/Social_networking" title="Social networking" class="mw-redirect">social networking</a> and <a href="/wiki/Social_bookmarking" title="Social bookmarking">bookmarking services</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
On <a href="/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">NBC</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bob_Costas" title="Bob Costas">Bob Costas</a> hosted the primetime telecast, while <a href="/wiki/Al_Michaels" title="Al Michaels">Al Michaels</a> did so during the day.  Together they co-hosted NBC's coverage of the  <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Winter_Olympics_Closing_Ceremony&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Winter Olympics Closing Ceremony (page does not exist)">Closing Ceremony</a>.
</p><p>In France, the Games were covered by <a href="/wiki/France_T%C3%A9l%C3%A9visions" title="France Télévisions">France Télévisions</a>, which included continuous live coverage on its website.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p><p>The official broadcast theme for the Olympic Broadcasting Services host broadcast was a piece called 'City Of Ice' composed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rob_May&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rob May (page does not exist)">Rob May</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Simon_Hill&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Simon Hill (page does not exist)">Simon Hill</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Torch_relay">Torch relay</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vancouver-Olympics-clock.jpg" title="File:Vancouver-Olympics-clock.jpg">File:Vancouver-Olympics-clock.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The clock counting down to the opening of Olympics Games in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Downtown_Vancouver&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Downtown Vancouver (page does not exist)">Downtown Vancouver</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The Olympic Torch Relay is the transfer of the Olympic flame from Ancient <a href="/wiki/Olympia,_Greece" title="Olympia, Greece">Olympia, Greece</a> — where the first Olympic Games were held thousands of years ago — to the stadium of the city hosting the current Olympic Games. The flame arrives just in time for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Winter_Olympics_opening_ceremony&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Winter Olympics opening ceremony (page does not exist)">Opening Ceremony</a>.
</p><p>For the Vancouver 2010 Olympic Winter Games, the flame was lit in Olympia on October 22, 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> It then traveled from <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a>, over the <a href="/wiki/North_Pole" title="North Pole">North Pole</a> to Canada's High Arctic and on to the West Coast and Vancouver. The relay started its long Canada journey from the British Columbia capital of <a href="/wiki/Victoria,_British_Columbia" title="Victoria, British Columbia">Victoria</a>. In Canada, the torch traveled approximately <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> over 106 days, making it the longest relay route within one country in Olympic history. The Olympic Torch was carried by approximately 12,000 Canadians and reached over 1,000 communities.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p><p>Celebrity torchbearers included <a href="/wiki/Arnold_Schwarzenegger" title="Arnold Schwarzenegger">Arnold Schwarzenegger</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-emotions_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-emotions-54">[54]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Steve_Nash" title="Steve Nash">Steve Nash</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Matt_Lauer" title="Matt Lauer">Matt Lauer</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Justin_Morneau" title="Justin Morneau">Justin Morneau</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Michael_Bubl%C3%A9" title="Michael Bublé">Michael Bublé</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bob_Costas" title="Bob Costas">Bob Costas</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Shania_Twain" title="Shania Twain">Shania Twain</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> and hockey greats including <a href="/wiki/Sidney_Crosby" title="Sidney Crosby">Sidney Crosby</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Wayne_Gretzky" title="Wayne Gretzky">Wayne Gretzky</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> and the captains of the two <a href="/wiki/Vancouver_Canucks" title="Vancouver Canucks">Vancouver Canucks</a> teams that went to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stanley_Cup_Finals&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stanley Cup Finals (page does not exist)">Stanley Cup Finals</a>: <a href="/wiki/Trevor_Linden" title="Trevor Linden">Trevor Linden</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Stanley_Cup_Finals_Year&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Stanley Cup Finals Year (page does not exist)">Template:Stanley Cup Finals Year</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Stan_Smyl" title="Stan Smyl">Stan Smyl</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Stanley_Cup_Finals_Year&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Stanley Cup Finals Year (page does not exist)">Template:Stanley Cup Finals Year</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Games">The Games</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Participating_National_Olympic_Committees">Participating National Olympic Committees</span></h3>
<p>82 <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Olympic_Committees&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Olympic Committees (page does not exist)">National Olympic Committees</a> (NOC) entered teams in the 2010 Winter Olympics.<sup id="cite_ref-WinterGames_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WinterGames-65">[65]</a></sup> Cayman Islands, Colombia, Ghana, Montenegro, Pakistan, Peru and Serbia made their winter Olympic debuts. Also Jamaica, Mexico and Morocco returned to the Games after missing the <a href="/wiki/2006_Winter_Olympics" title="2006 Winter Olympics">Turin Games</a>. Tonga sought to make its Winter Olympic debut by entering a single competitor in luge, attracting some media attention, but he crashed in the final round of qualifying.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup>
Luxembourg qualified two athletes<sup id="cite_ref-fis-ski.com_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fis-ski.com-67">[67]</a></sup> but did not participate because one did not reach the criteria set by the NOC<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> and the other was injured<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> before the Games.  Below is a map of the participating nations and a list of the nations with the number of competitors indicated in brackets.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="center"><div class="thumb tnone"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2010_Winter_Olympics_Participants.svg" title="File:2010 Winter Olympics Participants.svg">File:2010 Winter Olympics Participants.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">600px</div></div></div></div>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<div class="center">
<table class="wikitable collapsible" style="width:100%;">

</th></tr>
<tr>

</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Finland.svg" title="File:Flag of Finland.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Finland_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Finland at the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Finland</a>&#160;<span style="font-size:90%;">(95)</span><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup>

</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Georgia.svg" title="File:Flag of Georgia.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Georgia_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Georgia at the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Georgia</a>&#160;<span style="font-size:90%;">(8*)</span><sup id="cite_ref-athlete_71-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-athlete-71">[71]</a></sup> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Concerns_and_controversies_over_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Concerns and controversies over the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">*</a>)
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Multicol-break&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Multicol-break (page does not exist)">Template:Multicol-break</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Germany.svg" title="File:Flag of Germany.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Germany_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Germany at the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Germany</a>&#160;<span style="font-size:90%;">(153)</span><sup id="cite_ref-athlete_71-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-athlete-71">[71]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Ghana.svg" title="File:Flag of Ghana.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ghana at the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Ghana</a>&#160;<span style="font-size:90%;">(1)</span><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup>

<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_South_Africa.svg" title="File:Flag of South Africa.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Africa_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Africa at the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">South Africa</a>&#160;<span style="font-size:90%;">(2)</span><sup id="cite_ref-fis-ski.com_67-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fis-ski.com-67">[67]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Spain.svg" title="File:Flag of Spain.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spain_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spain at the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Spain</a>&#160;<span style="font-size:90%;">(18)</span><sup id="cite_ref-FigureSkating1_75-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FigureSkating1-75">[75]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FigureSkating2_76-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FigureSkating2-76">[76]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Sweden.svg" title="File:Flag of Sweden.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweden_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweden at the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Sweden</a>&#160;<span style="font-size:90%;">(106)</span><sup id="cite_ref-SwedishAthletes_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SwedishAthletes-93">[93]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Switzerland.svg" title="File:Flag of Switzerland.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Switzerland_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Switzerland at the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Switzerland</a>&#160;<span style="font-size:90%;">(146)</span><sup id="cite_ref-MensHockey_73-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MensHockey-73">[73]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Chinese_Taipei_for_Olympic_games.svg" title="File:Flag of Chinese Taipei for Olympic games.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_Taipei_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese Taipei at the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Chinese Taipei</a>&#160;<span style="font-size:90%;">(1)</span><sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Tajikistan.svg" title="File:Flag of Tajikistan.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tajikistan_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tajikistan at the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Tajikistan</a>&#160;<span style="font-size:90%;">(1)</span><sup id="cite_ref-athlete_71-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-athlete-71">[71]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Turkey.svg" title="File:Flag of Turkey.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Turkey_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Turkey at the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Turkey</a>&#160;<span style="font-size:90%;">(5)</span><sup id="cite_ref-athlete_71-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-athlete-71">[71]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Ukraine.svg" title="File:Flag of Ukraine.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ukraine_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ukraine at the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Ukraine</a>&#160;<span style="font-size:90%;">(47)</span><sup id="cite_ref-athlete_71-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-athlete-71">[71]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_the_United_States.svg" title="File:Flag of the United States.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States at the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">United States</a>&#160;<span style="font-size:90%;">(215)</span><sup id="cite_ref-athlete_71-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-athlete-71">[71]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Uzbekistan.svg" title="File:Flag of Uzbekistan.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Uzbekistan_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Uzbekistan at the 2010 Winter Olympics (page does not exist)">Uzbekistan</a>&#160;<span style="font-size:90%;">(3)</span><sup id="cite_ref-fis-ski.com_67-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fis-ski.com-67">[67]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Multicol-end&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Multicol-end (page does not exist)">Template:Multicol-end</a>
</p>
</td></tr></table>
<p>|}
</p>
</div>
<p>The following nations which competed at the previous Winter Games in <a href="/wiki/2006_Winter_Olympics" title="2006 Winter Olympics">Turin</a> did not participate in Vancouver:
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Costa_Rica_(state).svg" title="File:Flag of Costa Rica (state).svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Costa_Rica_at_the_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Costa Rica at the Olympics (page does not exist)">Costa Rica</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Kenya.svg" title="File:Flag of Kenya.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kenya_at_the_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kenya at the Olympics (page does not exist)">Kenya</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Luxembourg.svg" title="File:Flag of Luxembourg.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Luxembourg_at_the_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Luxembourg at the Olympics (page does not exist)">Luxembourg</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Madagascar.svg" title="File:Flag of Madagascar.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Madagascar_at_the_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Madagascar at the Olympics (page does not exist)">Madagascar</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Thailand.svg" title="File:Flag of Thailand.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/wiki/Thailand_at_the_Olympics" title="Thailand at the Olympics">Thailand</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_the_United_States_Virgin_Islands.svg" title="File:Flag of the United States Virgin Islands.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virgin_Islands_at_the_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virgin Islands at the Olympics (page does not exist)">Virgin Islands</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Venezuela.svg" title="File:Flag of Venezuela.svg">22x20px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Venezuela_at_the_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Venezuela at the Olympics (page does not exist)">Venezuela</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<p>86 events over 15 disciplines in 7 sports were included in the 2010 Winter Olympics. The three skating sports disciplines where <a href="/wiki/Figure_skating" title="Figure skating">figure skating</a>, <a href="/wiki/Speed_skating" title="Speed skating">speed skating</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Short_track_speed_skating" title="Short track speed skating">short track speed skating</a>. The six skiing sport disciplines where <a href="/wiki/Alpine_skiing" title="Alpine skiing">alpine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cross-country_skiing" title="Cross-country skiing">cross-country skiing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freestyle_skiing" title="Freestyle skiing">freestyle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nordic_combined" title="Nordic combined">Nordic combined</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ski_jumping" title="Ski jumping">ski jumping</a> and <a href="/wiki/Snowboarding" title="Snowboarding">snowboarding</a>. The two bobsleigh sports disciplines where <a href="/wiki/Bobsleigh" title="Bobsleigh">bobsleigh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Skeleton_(sport)" title="Skeleton (sport)">skeleton</a>. The other four sports were <a href="/wiki/Biathlon" title="Biathlon">biathlon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Curling" title="Curling">curling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey" title="Ice hockey">ice hockey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Luge" title="Luge">luge</a>. Numbers in parentheses indicate the number of medal events contested in each discipline.
</p>
<table style="width:100%;">

<tr>
<th><u>2010 Olympic Winter Sports Programme</u>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-begin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-begin (page does not exist)">Template:Col-begin</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-3&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-3 (page does not exist)">Template:Col-3</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:GamesSport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:GamesSport (page does not exist)">Template:GamesSport</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:GamesSport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:GamesSport (page does not exist)">Template:GamesSport</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:GamesSport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:GamesSport (page does not exist)">Template:GamesSport</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:GamesSport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:GamesSport (page does not exist)">Template:GamesSport</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:GamesSport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:GamesSport (page does not exist)">Template:GamesSport</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-3&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-3 (page does not exist)">Template:Col-3</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:GamesSport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:GamesSport (page does not exist)">Template:GamesSport</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:GamesSport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:GamesSport (page does not exist)">Template:GamesSport</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:GamesSport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:GamesSport (page does not exist)">Template:GamesSport</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:GamesSport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:GamesSport (page does not exist)">Template:GamesSport</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:GamesSport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:GamesSport (page does not exist)">Template:GamesSport</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-3&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-3 (page does not exist)">Template:Col-3</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:GamesSport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:GamesSport (page does not exist)">Template:GamesSport</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:GamesSport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:GamesSport (page does not exist)">Template:GamesSport</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:GamesSport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:GamesSport (page does not exist)">Template:GamesSport</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:GamesSport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:GamesSport (page does not exist)">Template:GamesSport</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:GamesSport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:GamesSport (page does not exist)">Template:GamesSport</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-end&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-end (page does not exist)">Template:Col-end</a>
</p>
</td></tr></table>
<p>The opening and closing ceremonies and the events categorized as ice sports (excluding bobsleigh, luge and skeleton) were held in Vancouver and Richmond. The sports categorized as "Nordic events" were held in the Callaghan Valley located just to the west of Whistler. All alpine skiing events were held on <a href="/wiki/Whistler_Blackcomb" title="Whistler Blackcomb">Whistler Mountain</a> (Creekside) and sliding events (bobsleigh, luge and skeleton) were held on <a href="/wiki/Whistler_Blackcomb" title="Whistler Blackcomb">Blackcomb Mountain</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cypress_Mountain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cypress Mountain (page does not exist)">Cypress Mountain</a> (located in <a href="/wiki/Cypress_Provincial_Park" title="Cypress Provincial Park">Cypress Provincial Park</a> in <a href="/wiki/West_Vancouver" title="West Vancouver">West Vancouver</a>) hosted the freestyle skiing (aerials, moguls and ski cross), and all snowboard events (half-pipe, parallel giant slalom, snowboard cross).
</p><p>Vancouver 2010 was also the first winter Olympics in which both men's and women's hockey were played on a narrower, <a href="/wiki/National_Hockey_League" title="National Hockey League">NHL</a>-sized ice rink,<sup id="cite_ref-VANOC_shrinks_ice_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VANOC_shrinks_ice-95">[95]</a></sup> measuring 200&#160;ft&#160;× 85&#160;ft (61&#160;m&#160;× 26&#160;m), instead of the international size of 200&#160;ft&#160;× 98.5&#160;ft (61&#160;m&#160;× 30&#160;m). The games were played at <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_Motors_Place&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="General Motors Place (page does not exist)">General Motors Place</a> (now Rogers Arena), home of the NHL's <a href="/wiki/Vancouver_Canucks" title="Vancouver Canucks">Vancouver Canucks</a>, which was temporarily renamed Canada Hockey Place for the duration of the Olympics. This change saved $10&#160;million in construction costs and allowed an additional 35,000 spectators to attend Olympic hockey games.<sup id="cite_ref-VANOC_shrinks_ice_95-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VANOC_shrinks_ice-95">[95]</a></sup> However, some European countries expressed concern over this decision, worried that it might give North American players an advantage since they grew up playing on the smaller NHL-sized rinks.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>There were a number of events that were proposed to be included in the 2010 Winter Olympics.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> On November 28, 2006, the IOC Executive Board at their meeting in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kuwait (page does not exist)">Kuwait</a> voted to include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ski_cross&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ski cross (page does not exist)">ski cross</a> in the official program.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> The Vancouver Olympic Committee (VANOC) subsequently approved the event to officially be part of the Games program.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup>
</p><p>Events proposed for inclusion but ultimately rejected included:<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Biathlon" title="Biathlon">Biathlon</a> mixed relay
</li>
<li> Mixed doubles <a href="/wiki/Curling" title="Curling">curling</a>
</li>
<li> Team <a href="/wiki/Alpine_skiing" title="Alpine skiing">alpine skiing</a>
</li>
<li> Team <a href="/wiki/Bobsled" title="Bobsled" class="mw-redirect">bobsled</a> and <a href="/wiki/Skeleton_(sport)" title="Skeleton (sport)">skeleton</a>
</li>
<li> Team <a href="/wiki/Luge" title="Luge">luge</a>
</li>
<li> Women's <a href="/wiki/Ski_jumping" title="Ski jumping">ski jumping</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The issue over women's ski jumping being excluded ended up in the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_British_Columbia" title="Supreme Court of British Columbia">Supreme Court of British Columbia</a> in Vancouver during April 21–24, 2009, with a verdict on July 10 excluding women's ski jumping from the 2010 Games.<sup id="cite_ref-wskijmp_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wskijmp-101">[101]</a></sup> A request to appeal that verdict to the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Canada" title="Supreme Court of Canada">Supreme Court of Canada</a> was subsequently denied on December 22 – a decision that marked the end of any hopes that the event would be held during Vancouver 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-wskijmpappeal_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wskijmpappeal-102">[102]</a></sup> To alleviate the exclusion, VANOC organizers invited women from all over Canada to participate at Whistler Olympic Park, including Continental Cup in January 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-wskijmp_101-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wskijmp-101">[101]</a></sup> There is now an effort to include women's ski jumping for the <a href="/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics" title="2014 Winter Olympics">2014 Winter Olympics</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sochi" title="Sochi">Sochi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-wskijmpsochi_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wskijmpsochi-103">[103]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Calendar">Calendar</span></h3>
<dl>
<dd><i>All times are in <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Standard_Time" title="Pacific Standard Time" class="mw-redirect">Pacific Standard Time</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=UTC-8&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UTC-8 (page does not exist)">UTC-8</a>)</i>
</dd>
</dl>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In the following calendar for the 2010 Winter Olympic Games, each blue box indicates that an event competition, such as a qualification round, was held on that day. The yellow boxes represent days during which medal-awarding finals for a sport were held with the number in these boxes representing the number of finals that were contested on that day.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:2010_Winter_Olympics_Calendar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:2010 Winter Olympics Calendar (page does not exist)">Template:2010 Winter Olympics Calendar</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Medal_table">Medal table</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>

</p>
