<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Concerns_and_controversies">Concerns and controversies</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Initial organized opposition to the games began in 2006 with the creation of No Games 2010<sup id="cite_ref-2010_Olympic_Games_Watch_homepage_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010_Olympic_Games_Watch_homepage-105">[105]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Who&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Who (page does not exist)">Template:Who</a> as outlined in Chris Shaw's book <i>Five Ring Circus</i> published in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-2010_Olympic_Games_Watch_homepage_105-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010_Olympic_Games_Watch_homepage-105">[105]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup>
The book has been widely reviewed and has been a touchstone for critics of the Vancouver Games.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup>
</p><p>Before the Games began and as they commenced, a number of concerns and controversies surfaced and received media attention.  Hours before the opening ceremony, Georgian <a href="/wiki/Luge" title="Luge">luger</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nodar_Kumaritashvili&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nodar Kumaritashvili (page does not exist)">Nodar Kumaritashvili</a> was killed during a training run, intensifying questions about the safety of the course and prompting<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> organizers to implement quick modifications. However, officials concluded that it was an athlete error rather than a track deficiency.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_Luge_Federation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International Luge Federation (page does not exist)">International Luge Federation</a> called an emergency meeting after the accident, and all other training runs were cancelled for the day.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc-crash_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-crash-112">[112]</a></sup>
</p><p>One critic<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup>
questioned the choice of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cypress_Mountain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cypress Mountain (page does not exist)">Cypress Mountain</a> as a venue because of its frequent lack of snow due to <a href="/wiki/El_Ni%C3%B1o" title="El Niño">El Niño</a>. Because of this possibility, organizers had a contingency plan to truck in snow from <a href="/wiki/Manning_Park" title="Manning Park" class="mw-redirect">Manning Park</a>, about <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> to the east of the city. This allowed events to proceed as planned.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup>
</p><p>Political decisions involving cancellation of promised low-income housing and the creation of a community of mixed economic backgrounds for post-Games use of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Olympic_Village&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Olympic Village (page does not exist)">athletes' village</a> was criticized.<sup id="cite_ref-Mackin_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mackin-115">[115]</a></sup>
</p><p>Opening ceremonies were stalled while organizers dealt with mechanical problems during the cauldron lighting ceremony.<sup id="cite_ref-mishaps_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mishaps-116">[116]</a></sup> Speed skating events were delayed due to breakdowns of the <a href="/wiki/Ice_resurfacer" title="Ice resurfacer">ice resurfacers</a> supplied by Olympia, an official sponsor of the Games.<sup id="cite_ref-ice_resurfacing_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ice_resurfacing-117">[117]</a></sup>
</p><p>Thousands of tickets were voided by organizers when weather conditions made standing-room-only areas unsafe.<sup id="cite_ref-spiegelol_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-spiegelol-118">[118]</a></sup> Visitors were also upset that, as in previous Olympics, medal ceremonies required separate admission<sup id="cite_ref-spiegelol_118-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-spiegelol-118">[118]</a></sup> and that blocks of VIP tickets reserved for sponsors and dignitaries were unused at events.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> Other glitches and complaints have included confusion by race officials at the start of the February 16 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Biathlon_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_pursuit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Biathlon at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Men's pursuit (page does not exist)">men's</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Biathlon_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_pursuit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Biathlon at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Women's pursuit (page does not exist)">women's biathlon pursuit</a> races, and restricted access to the Olympic flame cauldron on the Vancouver waterfront.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Opposition">Opposition</span></h3>
<p>Opposition to the Olympic Games was expressed by activists and politicians, including <a href="/wiki/Lower_Mainland" title="Lower Mainland">Lower Mainland</a> <a href="/wiki/Mayor" title="Mayor">mayors</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Derek_Corrigan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Derek Corrigan (page does not exist)">Derek Corrigan</a><sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup>
and <a href="/w/index.php?title=North_Vancouver,_British_Columbia_(district_municipality)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="North Vancouver, British Columbia (district municipality) (page does not exist)">Richard Walton</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> Many of the public pre-Olympic events held in Vancouver were attended by <a href="/wiki/Protest" title="Protest">protesters</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>On Saturday, February 13, as part of a week-long Anti-Olympic Convergence, protesters smashed windows of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Downtown_Vancouver&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Downtown Vancouver (page does not exist)">Downtown Vancouver</a> location of <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Bay&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Bay (page does not exist)">The Bay</a> <a href="/wiki/Department_store" title="Department store">department store</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> Protesters later argued that the owner of The Bay, the <a href="/wiki/Hudson%27s_Bay_Company" title="Hudson's Bay Company">Hudson's Bay Company</a>, "has been a symbol of <a href="/wiki/Colonialism" title="Colonialism">colonial oppression</a> for centuries" as well as a major sponsor of the 2010 Olympics.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup>
</p><p>There were several other reasons for the opposition, some of which are outlined in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Helen_Jefferson_Lenskyj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Helen Jefferson Lenskyj (page does not exist)">Helen Jefferson Lenskyj</a>'s books <i>Olympic Industry Resistance</i> (2007) and <i>Inside the Olympic Industry</i> (2000).<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup>
These issues include:
</p>
<ul>
<li> Displacement of <a href="/wiki/Low-income" title="Low-income" class="mw-redirect">low-income</a> residents.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> Anticipated <a href="/w/index.php?title=Human_trafficking&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Human trafficking (page does not exist)">human trafficking</a> for the purpose of forced prostitution.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="First_Nations_opposition">First Nations opposition</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Native_Warrior_Society_-_Olympic_Flag.jpg" title="File:Native Warrior Society - Olympic Flag.jpg">File:Native Warrior Society - Olympic Flag.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Vancouver 2010 Olympic Flag and its captors, the Native Warrior Society</div></div></div>
<p>Although the Aboriginal governments of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Squamish_Nation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Squamish Nation (page does not exist)">Squamish</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Musqueam_Indian_Band&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Musqueam Indian Band (page does not exist)">Musqueam</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lil%27wat_First_Nation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lil'wat First Nation (page does not exist)">Lil'wat</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tsleil-Waututh_First_Nation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tsleil-Waututh First Nation (page does not exist)">Tsleil-Waututh</a> (the "Four Host First Nations"), on whose traditional territory the Games were held, signed a protocol in 2004<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup> in support of the games,<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> there was opposition to the Olympics from some <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indigenous_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indigenous people (page does not exist)">indigenous</a> groups and supporters.  Although the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lil%27wat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lil'wat (page does not exist)">Lil'wat</a> branch of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=St%27at%27imc_Nation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="St'at'imc Nation (page does not exist)">St'at'imc Nation</a> is a co-host of the Games, a splinter group from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Seton_Lake_First_Nation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Seton Lake First Nation (page does not exist)">Seton</a> band known as the St’at’imc of Sutikalh, who have also opposed the Cayoosh Ski Resort, feared the Olympics would bring unwanted tourism and real estate sales to their territory.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup>  Local aboriginal people, as well as Canadian <a href="/w/index.php?title=Inuit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Inuit (page does not exist)">Inuit</a>, initially expressed concern over the choice of an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Inukshuk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Inukshuk (page does not exist)">inukshuk</a> as the symbol of the Games, with some Inuit leaders such as former <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nunavut&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nunavut (page does not exist)">Nunavut</a> Commissioner <a href="/wiki/Peter_Irniq" title="Peter Irniq">Peter Irniq</a> stating that the inukshuk is a culturally important symbol to them. He said that the "Inuit never build inuksuit with head, legs and arms. I have seen inuksuit [built] more recently, 100 years maybe by non-Inuit in Nunavut, with head, legs and arms. These are not called inuksuit. These are called <a href="/w/index.php?title=Inunguat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Inunguat (page does not exist)">inunguat</a>, imitation of man."<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> Local aboriginal groups also expressed annoyance that the design did not reflect the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Coast_Salish_peoples&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Coast Salish peoples (page does not exist)">Coast Salish</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Interior_Salish&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Interior Salish (page does not exist)">Interior Salish</a> native culture from the region the Games are being held in, but rather that of the Inuit, who are indigenous to the Arctic far from Vancouver.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Doping">Doping</span></h3>
<p>On March 11, 2010, it was reported that the Polish cross country skier <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kornelia_Marek&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kornelia Marek (page does not exist)">Kornelia Marek</a> was tested positive for <a href="/wiki/Erythropoietin" title="Erythropoietin">EPO</a> by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Polish_Olympic_Committee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Polish Olympic Committee (page does not exist)">Polish Olympic Committee</a>. If found guilty of doping by the International Olympic Committee, Marek and the relay teams would be disqualified and stripped of their Vancouver results. She would also be banned from the <a href="/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics" title="2014 Winter Olympics">next Winter Olympics</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sochi" title="Sochi">Sochi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>, in 2014.
</p><p>Marek denied taking any banned substances, but the backup "B" sample from the Vancouver doping lab confirmed the "A" sample.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span></h2>
<p>The massive celebratory crowds in downtown Vancouver were highly praised by the IOC. <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Rogge" title="Jacques Rogge">Jacques Rogge</a>, the president of IOC, indicated that "the way Vancouver embraced these Games was extraordinary.  This is really something unique and has given a great atmosphere for these Games."<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup>  Only very few members of the media (mostly, and particularly the <a href="/wiki/Media_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Media of the United Kingdom">British media</a>) criticized the Own the Podium and criticized the celebrations as having been somewhat nationalistic,<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> but this was not an opinion shared by many.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup>  The atmosphere surrounding the Olympics, and its inclusion of foreign delegates and guests, was also praised, with many seasoned Winter Olympic observers putting the games at, or near, the top of the list of best ever Winter Olympics.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup>  They were also the best watched Winter Olympics since the <a href="/wiki/1994_Olympics" title="1994 Olympics" class="mw-redirect">1994 Olympics</a> in Lillehammer.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> They are also mentioned alongside the <a href="/wiki/Sydney_2000" title="Sydney 2000" class="mw-redirect">Sydney 2000</a> Summer games in regards to the best atmosphere. A large part is credited to the citizens of Vancouver and Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Vancouver Olympics also organized and hosted the first Pride House for <a href="/wiki/LGBT" title="LGBT">LGBT</a> athletes in the history of the event.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Funding">Funding</span></h3>
<p>Directly as a result of Canada's medal performance at the 2010 Olympics, the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Canada" title="Government of Canada">Government of Canada</a> announced in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Canadian_federal_budget&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Canadian federal budget (page does not exist)">2010 federal budget</a>, a new commitment of $34 million over the next two years towards programs for athletes planning to compete in future Olympics.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup>  This is in addition to the $11 million per year federal government commitment to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Own_the_Podium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Own the Podium (page does not exist)">Own the Podium</a> program.
</p><p>Also, as a result of hosting the 2010 Olympics, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_Columbia_government&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British Columbia government (page does not exist)">British Columbia government</a> pledged to restore funding for sports programs and athlete development to 2008 levels, which amounts to $30 million over three years.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<p>{{#invoke:Portal|portal}}
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IOC_seealso&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IOC seealso (page does not exist)">Template:IOC seealso</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Winter_Olympics_victory_ceremonies&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Winter Olympics victory ceremonies (page does not exist)">2010 Winter Olympics victory ceremonies</a>
</li>
<li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_%26_Sonic_at_the_Olympic_Winter_Games&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mario &amp; Sonic at the Olympic Winter Games (page does not exist)">Mario &amp; Sonic at the Olympic Winter Games</a></i>, a 2009 crossover video game between the <i>Mario</i> and <i>Sonic the Hedgehog</i> series released for the <a href="/wiki/Nintendo_DS" title="Nintendo DS">Nintendo DS</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wii" title="Wii">Wii</a>.
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<dl>
<dd><b>A.</b> <span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_note01"><sup></sup></span>  Miga and Quatchi were mascots for the Olympic Games, while Sumi was the mascot for the Paralympic Games. Mukmuk is considered a <a href="/wiki/Sidekick" title="Sidekick">sidekick</a>, not a full mascot.
</dd>
</dl>
